title: What are Semiconductors?
content:
Materials with electrical conductivity between conductors and insulators.
Their conductivity can be controlled by doping or applying an electric field.
Essential components in modern electronics.
image_desc:
A diagram showing the energy band gap in a semiconductor compared to a conductor and an insulator. Type: diagram

### Video Suggestion:
[No video suggestion]
narration: Semiconductors are materials that fall between conductors and insulators in terms of their electrical conductivity.  Their unique property lies in their ability to have their conductivity precisely controlled by adding impurities a process called doping or by applying an electric field. This controllability is what makes them so crucial in modern electronics.

title: Types of Semiconductors
content:
**Column 1: Intrinsic Semiconductors**
Pure semiconductors with no significant impurities.
Conductivity depends on temperature.
Examples: pure silicon and germanium.
**Column 2: Extrinsic Semiconductors**
Impurities added to alter conductivity.
N-type: doped with donor impurities (e.g., phosphorus).
P-type: doped with acceptor impurities (e.g., boron).
image_desc:
A diagram illustrating the difference between intrinsic and extrinsic semiconductors, showing the addition of dopants. Type: diagram

narration: Semiconductors are broadly categorized into intrinsic and extrinsic types. Intrinsic semiconductors are pure with minimal impurities and their conductivity is largely temperaturedependent. Extrinsic semiconductors on the other hand have impurities added to enhance their conductivity.  These impurities can be donor atoms creating ntype semiconductors or acceptor atoms creating ptype semiconductors.

title: Applications of Semiconductors
content:
Integrated circuits (microchips)
Transistors
Diodes
LEDs
Solar cells

narration: The applications of semiconductors are vast and impact nearly every aspect of modern life. They are the fundamental building blocks of integrated circuits or microchips which power our computers smartphones and countless other devices.  They also form the basis of transistors diodes LEDs and solar cells showcasing their versatility and importance.
